title.value: Interpretable domain adaptation using unsupervised feature selection on pre-trained source models
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Interpretable domain adaptation using unsupervised feature selection on pre-trained source models

extractions.description: This paper proposes a domain adaptation method that operates without retraining existing pre-trained models. Instead, the method uses a feature selection process to adapt the target domain data to the source model. The proposed solution addresses both weakly-supervised and unsupervised domain adaptation, particularly when dealing with tabular data that have categorical and numerical attributes. It introduces a pseudo-label estimation technique for unlabeled data and aims to provide interpretable target-to-source transformations.

type.justification: The paper provides theoretical foundations for the proposed unsupervised feature selection method for domain adaptation.
type.quote: We provide theoretical foundations of our method as well as an efficient implementation.

name.justification: The paper focuses primarily on domain adaptation methods, proposing a new method for target to source data transformation.
name.quote: Domain adaptation (DA) methods deal with a scenario where training data, the so-called source domain data, and test data, the so-called target domain data, are drawn from different distributions.

name.justification: The paper discusses unsupervised feature selection as a major component of the proposed domain adaptation technique.
name.quote: We study a realistic domain adaptation setting where one has access to an already existing ‘‘black-box” machine learning model... To automatically select the subset of features to be adapted, we first introduce a weakly-supervised process relying on scarce labeled target data.

name.justification: The paper uses fraud detection as an example application of the proposed domain adaptation method.
name.quote: For example, to expand companies’ businesses, a payment fraud detection system trained in one geographical localization, say one country (source domain), may be used to detect fraudsters in another country (target domain) where people have different payment habits.

name.justification: The paper mentions using a pre-trained black-box model repeatedly, emphasizing its role in the proposed domain adaptation method.
name.quote: Indeed, in real-life scenarios, an efficient pre-trained source domain predictive model is often available and required to be preserved.

is_contributed.justification: While the model is used as a reference point in the research, the paper does not contribute this model.
is_contributed.quote: Indeed, in real-life scenarios, an efficient pre-trained source domain predictive model is often available and required to be preserved.

is_executed.justification: The paper discusses using the pre-trained model without retraining rather than executing it as part of an experiment inside the paper.
is_executed.quote: Moreover, we propose to stand in a target to source DA scenario: one transforms target data into the source ones and predicts target domain labels using the pre-trained source model directly without supplementary retraining.

is_compared.justification: While the paper proposes a method for adapting to the pre-trained model, it inherently compares the traditional need to retrain models with this new method.
is_compared.quote: However, such methods require retraining a predictive model after or during the adaptation, which is undesirable in a real-life industrial setting.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not cite a specific reference paper for the pre-trained black-box model used in its context.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Indeed, in real-life scenarios, an efficient pre-trained source domain predictive model is often available and required to be preserved.
